Expectation1: Maintain laboratory equipment and ensure safety protocols are followed
Situation1: The routine maintenance checklist is coming up soon, but no malfunctions have been noted.
Situation2: Multiple ID types are acceptable, and spare cards can still be fetched later in the day.
Story: I glanced at the calendar on my lab wall, the red circle around “maintenance checklist” glaring at me. As the lead scientist, I’m expected to ensure every piece of equipment is checked, every safety protocol followed, even if nothing seems amiss. It’s a responsibility I take seriously—one overlooked detail could mean disaster. But today is also election day. As a voter, I’m expected to show up with valid ID, ready to participate in the process I believe in. I have my driver’s license, but my passport and other cards are at home, just in case. I could fetch them later, but the lab’s schedule is tight, and my team relies on me to oversee the checks. My mind races: if I rush the checklist, I risk missing something critical; if I delay voting, I might not make it back in time before the polls close. The weight of both roles presses on me, each demanding my presence, each unwilling to wait. I stand in the lab, torn, the hum of machines echoing my inner turmoil.
